newsitem.title: FRANCE: Santer says treaty stalemate threatens enlargement.
newsitem.headline: Santer says treaty stalemate threatens enlargement.

text.p: European Commission President Jacques Santer warned the European Union on Wednesday that a stalemate in EU treaty talks threatened prospects for bringing new members from eastern Europe into the bloc.

Reflecting concerns that negotiations on a new EU treaty would not properly prepare the bloc for enlargement, Santer said no country should assume that a second set of talks could be undertaken while the EU also negotiated with potential members.

"I am in favour of enlargement," Santer told the European Parliament. "But I must make clear that the scenario will come to nothing if the (new treaty) does not provide a solution to the institutional challenges posed by enlargement."
The EU has told 12 eastern European and Mediterranean countries they can eventually join the bloc, but said that EU institutions must first be reformed to pave the way.

That is being done in the so-called inter-governmental conference (IGC), due to be completed in mid-1997. A number of critics, however, have charged that the pace and scope of the negotiations are not robust enough to get the job done.
Some have privately suggested a second IGC may be needed to clear up what the current talks cannot agree.
"The mind boggles at the idea of holding a second IGC, a play-off as it were, before the end of the century," Santer said.

"I must emphatically discourage any such notion. Do we really want to carry on external accession (membership) negotiations and discussions on internal institutional reform at the same time?" he said.
